etymologies: mid 17th century: from French tonique, from Greek tonikos ‘of or for stretching’, from tonos (see tone)

definitions: a medicinal substance taken to give a feeling of vigour or well-being.
shortDefinitions: medicinal substance taken to give feeling of vigour or well-being

examples.text: being needed is a tonic for someone at my age

definitions: the first note in a scale which, in conventional harmony, provides the keynote of a piece of music.
shortDefinitions: first note in scale which, in conventional harmony, provides keynote of piece of music

definitions: giving a feeling of vigour or well-being; invigorating
shortDefinitions: giving feeling of vigour or well-being

definitions: relating to or denoting the first degree of a scale.
denoting or relating to the syllable within a tone group that has greatest prominence, because it carries the main change of pitch.
shortDefinitions: denoting or relating to syllable within tone group that has greatest prominence, because it carries main change of pitch

definitions: relating to or restoring normal tone to muscles or other organs.
shortDefinitions: relating to or restoring normal tone to muscles or other organs

definitions: relating to, denoting, or producing continuous muscular contraction.
shortDefinitions: relating to, denoting, or producing continuous muscular contraction
